Patient: Mirta Langosh
NHS Number: 3598284446
Date of Birth: September 4, 1964

Chief Complaint: Right sinus pressure and congestion for 1 week. Yellow nasal discharge for 2 days. Temperature: 101.5°F (38.6°C).

History of Present Illness: The patient presents with a 1-week history of right sinus pressure and congestion, accompanied by yellow nasal discharge for the past 2 days. She reports difficulty breathing through her nose and has experienced some facial pain and pressure.

Review of Systems: The patient's review of systems is unremarkable except for the sinus symptoms.

Assessment: Based on the patient's symptoms, I suspect a bacterial sinusitis. I recommend a nasal swab for culture and sensitivity to guide antibiotic therapy.

Plan: Order a nasal swab for culture and sensitivity. Prescribe amoxicillin 500mg orally twice daily for 7-10 days, pending results of the nasal swab. Instruct patient to continue using saline nasal spray as needed for symptomatic relief.

Note: This is just an example and may not reflect current medical knowledge or practices. Always consult a licensed healthcare professional for accurate diagnosis and treatment.

Certainly! Here is an example clinical note for Dr. McLaughlin's patient, Rosario:

Patient Name: Rosario McLaughlin
NHS Number: 7487550869
Date of Birth: September 7, 1987
Given Name: Rosario
Family Name: McLaughlin
Diagnosis: Chronic intractable migraine without aura

Rosario presented to the clinic today with complaints of frequent and severe headaches that have been ongoing for several months. She reports that the headaches are debilitating and interfere with her daily activities. She has tried various treatments, including over-the-counter pain medications and lifestyle modifications, but has not experienced any significant improvement. A thorough examination revealed no obvious causes of the headaches. Based on the patient's history and presentation, I diagnose chronic intractable migraine without aura and recommend further evaluation and treatment options to manage her symptoms.
